title: The Importance of Consistency and Behavior Modification
content: Layne Norton emphasizes the importance of consistency and behavior modification in achieving fitness goals. He notes that binging on junk food or blowing money on a shopping spree are due to behaviors that must be modified and new positive habits must be created. Marie Spreckley's systematic review found that maintenance of weight loss was associated with consistency and the ability to embrace challenges rather than running from them or viewing challenges as part of the process. Norton also stresses the need to change one's mindset from 'I have to exercise' to 'I am a fit person who exercises' to make it easier to do day in and day out.

title: Forming a New Identity
content: According to Norton, forming a new identity is crucial in achieving fitness goals. He cites Ethan Suplee, who lost a tremendous amount of weight and formed a new identity, as an example. Norton notes that you cannot create a new life while still dragging old behaviors behind you and that you must give some old habits up. He stresses that people need to persist after the honeymoon phase when facing their first challenge or setback.

title: The Role of Motivation and Consistency
content: Norton believes that motivation is not the key to achieving fitness goals, but rather consistency and aligning one's actions with the amount of work needed. He compares exercise to brushing his teeth, noting that he doesn't need to be motivated to do it because if he doesn't, his body will suffer. Norton stresses that people need to buy in and persist after the honeymoon phase when facing their first challenge or setback.

title: Consistency is Key
content: Participants in the systematic review said it was difficult to see their weight fluctuate; Layne tells them to weigh in every single day and take the average. “The point of this all is that consistency is the fundamental… You could have any diet. You could have any training system. If you’re consistent, you’re going to see results”

title: Practice Makes Perfect
content: If you tried to be the best 3-point shooter you could be, and you practiced every single day for three hours a day for 10 years, you probably wouldn’t be in the NBA, but even with no instruction, coach, or books, you’d be pretty damn good at shooting three pointers

title: Be Careful When Comparing Yourself to Others
content: Layne says to use other people’s stories for inspiration, but be very careful about comparing yourself. Don’t ask yourself if you can be like a specific person but instead if you can get better. When he started out, other people told him he wouldn’t be good at weightlifting. If he had listened to them, he never would have won a gold medal in the squat

title: Consistency Can Make Up for Shortcomings
content: “I got a lot farther than I ever could have imagined just through sheer consistency. I did a lot of stuff wrong, but sheer mass effect of work and consistency can make up for a lot of shortcomings.” —Layne Norton
